newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX crude ends lower on Iraqi troop withdrawal.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX crude ends lower on Iraqi troop withdrawal.

text.p: NYMEX crude prices ended lower Wednesday on news that Iraqi troops had pulled out of Kurdish regions in northern Iraq, but selling was limited by continued uncertainty in the region.

"It was a combination of the uncertainty and the fundamentals. We are still not getting 700,000 barrels," said Rita Beale, an analyst with Fimat USA Futures, of the limited sell off following news of the Iraqi troop withdrawal.
October crude settled off 16 cents to $23.24 a barrel. October heating oil fell 0.86 cent to 64.21 cents a gallon while October gasoline ended unchanged at 62.96 cents.

The sharper drop in heating oil futures reflected weakness in the cash market where heating oil and low sulphur diesel differentials slipped by about 0.35/0.40 cent a gallon from yesterday, a trader said.
Traders said the weaker cash prices may have been in anticipation of the higher-than-expected weekly heating oil stocks reported by the American Petroleum Institute Wednesday evening.
Just the same, Beale expects the oil complex to continue its general trend upward.
"The uptrend is still in place," Fimat's Beale said.
The United Nations suspended the Iraqi oil-for-food deal on Sunday in response to military incursions by Iraqi troops into Kurdish territories in northern Iraq.
Analysts estimate the deal would have added about 700,000 barrels a day of Iraqi oil to the market.
Meanwhile, traders remain cautious of further developments in Iraq which could destabilize the region and drive oil prices higher.
"You never know what's going to happen. So they (the troops) have withdrawn? I am real skeptical," a trader said.
-- Harry Milling, New York Energy Desk, +1 212-859-1761
